name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Based on the medical advice she received, the understanding is that covid acted like some kind of multiplier, weakening her body and its ability to cope. She's now looking at up to 6 months of pain and trying to manage that pain, and who knows after that.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Even before getting covid, the pain that comes with endometriosis was difficult enough. We were hoping that she'd eventually be able to 'manage' the pain and decrease it with the various treatments she was going through. Now with covid we have no idea.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Other days, it's 'just' headaches or 'just' joint pains. There is almost no day without some kind of pain. Now with the research on #longcovid coming out, we are really worried that this means a very long time with various health problems that could've been avoided without covid

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: As in she was bedridden for a couple of days - I don't even want to imagine what it would be like without the vaccine - and then 'relatively functioning' afterward, but only temporarily. Since then it's been on and off, some days the pains are completely paralyzing

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Every day since getting covid she's been in a lot of pain, only decreasing temporarily w/ paracetamol and ibuprofen + as of yest opioids bcs the former two weren't enough. Intense migraines especially, joint pains too. And this was a 'mild' case of covid by any other measures

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet:
"an Italian mission massacred in Ethiopia" 9 July 1936

Le Petit Parisien ran from 1876 to 1944. Started of as radical left and anti-clerical. They were initially complicit in the Dreyfus affair but then defended Dreyfus against antisemitism. https://t.co/Y3bFgAquyo

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Above one has this image which reads "indigenous Eritreans, loyal to the Italians, in progress on the sand dunes". On the right is an automobile show lol, celebrating the "1936 car" https://t.co/qy1AJnpiBT

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet:
"the Italo-Ethiopian war begins" October 4 1935

L'intransigeant ran from 1880 to 1948. It's an odd one. It started off as far left post-Paris commune (1870-71) and then became far right in the 1890s. They were part of the Dreyfus affair, and interviewed Hitler in 1934 https://t.co/r3HuFKYoCh

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet:
"Axum isn't in fascist hands. Adigrat will be taken back by the Ethiopians" October 10, 1935

L'humanité, paper of the French communist party until 1994, founded by socialist Jean Jaurès (assassinated by a nationalist in 1914) https://t.co/hyTvyy6GMz

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet:
Also from above: "today March 5 (1935) at 4pm, at the head of the victorious troupes I have entered Addis Abeba" - Badoglio. 

Pietro Badoglio was the first viceroy of Italian East Africa (1936-1941). After Mussolini, he became Prime Minister of Italy https://t.co/y5Ai8IgPRd

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet:
"Mussolini announces to the Italian people and to the world that the war is over [...] Ethiopia is Italian". March 6, 1936.

Gazzetta del Popolo ran from 1848 to 1983. Editor at the time of this headline was the fascist regime-approved Eugenio Bertuetti. https://t.co/g31U6STy7j

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It took me 2+ yrs in 🇨🇭 - WITH a pandemic - to get over it. The 2 years at Edinburgh Uni ('17-19) were so bad that the past 2 years of remote work, loneliness and pandemic shit felt like a relief in comparison. How insane is that? (with all the usual caveats about 🇨🇭)

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: There is something that I still can't get over about how shit the PhD experience in the UK was. At every step of the way I was made to feel unwelcome and expendable. It was actually abusive. I thought I was losing my mind for just wanting to actually be able to do a PhD

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: So some good academia news (I know, 'good news' and 'academia' in the same sentence?) I probably got some long-term stability. Besides the relief which I'm currently experiencing, I think I'm also slowly finally recovering from the trauma of UK academia 3 years on.

I took the above photos in the summer of 2011 in Ambohibola, Madagascar.

Even back then there was neither running water nor electricity, and obviously no internet. 

Southern Madagascar has barely had any rain in the past 5 years.

It's a catastrophe.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Meanwhile everyone I know is wondering who's the first Lebanese politician who'll meet a fate similar to Gaddafi's. People really need to understand the level of anger we're dealing with. They took everything from us.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It really is weird seeing the disconnect to be honest. I keep on seeing pieces that either suggest Lebanon is 'on the brink' (of what? it's already 'there') or that somehow this regime will accept 'reforms' that necessarily require its own downfall if we keep on asking it nicely.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: None of these politicians can safely walk on the streets of Lebanon without significant numbers of armed men. They can't sleep in their own houses without even more security all around. Lebanon isn't safe for them. They didn't stay in power this long by not knowing this.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: How's this for symbolism? The hospital where he died was itself terribly damaged by the port explosion. He died there just a few months prior. Had he lasted a bit longer, that day of horror could have been his last one on this planet. https://t.co/TP87anyeOv

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: We hope that our grandparents never have to go to the hospital or need medicine. This is why I was relieved that my grandfather passed away early last year, just as the pandemic was declared. The way the wind was blowing was already obvious then. And that was before the explosion

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Kids have died due to a shortage of medication, elderly have died due to a shortage of oxygen in hospitals, other ppl have died by suicide. The situation is really grim, and it is only rational to expect that this will make a lot of ppl feel like they have nothing more to lose.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: I must have repeated this in like 10 different podcast interviews since 2019. The only plan is to postpone, and then to postpone some more, and then some more, and hope that people just get used to an even lower quality of life. Except this time, it's simply unlivable.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: But now we're at the stage where people have lost loved ones to the port explosion last year and we're coming near the one year commemoration on August 4th. The economy is in shatters, basic necessities like medicine are disappearing, and they have no plan.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: You can murder journalists, activists, prime ministers, activists and everyone knows, the day of the murder itself, that there won't be accountability. We all knew that after the port of Beirut explosion, despite the circus around foreign politicians pretending to be concerned

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: They don't want to remove legal immunities because it can lead to a domino effect. The entirety of the 'postwar' establishment relies on the fact that accountability must *never* be a thing, with only the most insignificant of exceptions.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: The interior minister needs an armored vehicle to escort him from his own house because relatives of those killed in the Beirut port explosion last year are demanding that he removes the legal immunities preventing a judge from investigating it. https://t.co/uklQA13c8E

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: So much of the coverage I keep on seeing about Lebanon seems unable to understand that the anger we're witnessing is already beyond talks of 'reforms'. This regime cannot be reformed. The politicians, if they're smart, know that their lives are on the line.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: The role of elites - elite panic, hording, financial speculation etc - is the story of much of our world's failures, past and present. This is one of the legacy of the great famine, and it goes beyond Lebanon. Just thinking of Tigray today @GeorgeMonbiot https://t.co/51dLfe8PRX

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It would be one thing - bad enough - to deal with a locust plague when you know you can wait it out because there's enough grain stored in your village. It's quite another to deal with it when the Ottomans (from Syria) and the Allies (from the Sea) are already blocking the grains

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Natural causes exist (the locust plague being the obvious one in the case of Mount Lebanon) but these usually exacerbate existing elite-made disasters. The role of the elites - from Djemal Pasha to the Sursocks and others to the Allies in WWI - is significantly worse.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: One thing that is really striking about the Great Famine of Mount Lebanon is what is usually striking about most famines. Despite popular beliefs, they are - most of the time - largely man-made. Famines are the stories of how resources are distributed in our societies.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: My family (the Lebanese side, which is most of them) was deeply affected by the famine. They're all from Mount Lebanon. There's a reason I have the Argentinian citizenship, and it ain't a cheerful one. Most of my ancestors who could leave left, and they went anywhere they could.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: I am currently preparing the @FireTheseTimes episode with @warghetti and @timourazhari on the legacy of the Great Famine of Mount Lebanon. I thought I was fairly immune to the stories, having read them so many times already, but I was quite wrong.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: 2016 was quite the crash course in dismantling all these illusions. I learned the hard way that most activists I met didn't know much about any place that wasn't cool to know about in their own circles, and that was that.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Alt-imperialism works well because it reproduces the same logic employed by anyone who defends imperialism. They very rarely outright say 'yes but America is always the best'. It's almost always 'yes, but China/Russia'. Same for alt-imperialists, with their 'yes, but America' 4/4

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Keep the focus on themselves. Any analysis of China or Russia has to be about America because they have a lot more to say about America. That way, they don't actually have to know much about Russia or China. They don't need to speak to Uighurs or Syrians or Ukrainians 3/4

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It achieves the same result: erasing the specificity of what China and Russia are doing in their respective contexts. It erases Georgians, Ukrainians, Syrians, Uighurs, Hong Kongers, Taiwanese etc as @Mortis_Banned said. This is the most efficient ways Tankies have found to 2/4

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: this is what I mean when I called this phenomenon alt-imperialism. The idea isn't even to always deny Russian or Chinese imperialism, but to simply always make sure any discussions about Russia/China is downgraded to a 'but America is worse'. 1/4 https://t.co/rrr7umziul

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: This is why we need to let go of just trying to call them out, and put our weight behind those resisting the state's authoritarian apparatus (the cops, in this case) on the streets. The politics of respectability - super widespread in the UK - benefits authoritarianism.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: The 'logical' next step is simply more of this, with the state becoming increasingly violent. The state will push people more and more until it finds a new equilibrium, with increased power to the police (and eventually the security services).

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: This has its roots in the 'hostile environment', even before Brexit. Most of those who were brutalized at the time were non-Brits and it therefore didn't get the attention it deserved from the left. Now the violence is being redirected towards citizens.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: There is no plan for Brexit. There is no plan B. There is no way out of this mess. There is nothing they can do, so all they will do is what they already know. The tried and tested tactics that have always led to a progressive decline into authoritarianism.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: This is how we go from talking about the state's victims to specific tactics used by the state. 'Isn't this going too far? we start asking, because they are the ones framing the problem, and therefore framing our realities.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: This is how the state takes away attention from the underlying causes of any problem, and this is very difficult to do without the complicity of media institutions. Again, there is nothing left for the Tories to do but double and triple down.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: I see the #MilkTeaAlliance as a good potential alternative to that as it decenters 'the West' and allows people from Hong Kong, Taiwan, Thailand, Myanmar and other places to amplify one another. It needs to be emulated everywhere else and adapted to local contexts.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: We now have the data to show that simply 'showing' evidence to someone in denial doesn't always work, so we need to balance that with the fact that it is sometimes still needed. It's more a question of how much time we dedicate to doing just that, and what then doesn't get done.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet:
I don't think we (myself included) fully understand how much faster lies spread on the internet, and how there simply is no way of catching up with them all. It is literally impossible. 

Spending too much time doing that means we can't do other important work.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: There was no way Syrians in 2011 could have known just how massive and effective the online disinformation campaigns against them would soon be (especially after Russia intervened in 2015, but honestly as early as 2012 or so too.)

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: To be clear (and fair), the Arab Spring happened back when most folks were more optimistic about social media. The negative effects weren't as visible as they are now, particularly the ways in which powerful actors can use these tools to silence dissent.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It is a matter of how much time is spent on each task (debunking vs organizing etc). In retrospect, I think we spent too much time trying to debunk online trolls and authoritarians, who were overwhelmingly westerners, and not enough time amplifying one another.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: I honestly think the best way to deal with online denial of ongoing crimes by Myanmar's military dictatorship is to actively build more bonds, and to spend less time refuting deniers. The #MilkTeaAlliance is a good alternative to one of the shortcomings of the Arab Spring 🧵⬇️

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Repeating what many of us have been saying for nearly a decade now: Scapegoating Syrians (and Palestinians) is the only consistent position of the Lebanese government https://t.co/mCuejomLuZ

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Either they go full Assadism in Lebanon, which I still doubt they would, or they attempt to delay everything for as long as possible. Their 'Resistance' with a capital R has been malleable so far. I don't know how long it can last.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: This is when alternative voices come out, even if that's been slowed down by the pandemic. We saw it in October 2019, we've seen it since and we'll see it again. I'll repeat: Hezbollah has no plan other than the one they already know.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Now, Hezbollah is stuck. They can't do another 1980s again. They can't kill off Lebanese communists and still be accepted because of their resistance against Israeli occupation. They can't kill off Syrians and use that to scare the Lebanese. There's no one left to kill.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It's why in 2015 there weren't that many efforts to tackle the Hezbollah question in the protest movement. It was too complicated, and many of us simply accepted (or internalized) their 'war on terror'. The hatred of Syrians goes beyond Hezbollah in Lebanon.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: This worked for a while because conditions in Lebanon were not catastrophic enough. We were able to outsource that catastrophe to Syrians and, again, there is very little political cost to murdering Syrians in Lebanon.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: They need to display their power routinely. It can't just sit there. It has to be used.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: The 'war on terror' is addictive. Like any good conspiracy theory - I know they're not the same, but they have similarities - the enemy is always vague and always elusive. He (always a he - men only thinking about men) is both incredibly powerful and pathetically weak.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: For now, they know that killing too many Lebanese (unlike killing Syrians) is too politically costly. That's as 'good' as it gets. But I'll repeat again that this is temporary, and my fear of what they could do next goes even beyond Lokman Slim's assassination.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Because everything they've done to us they have done significantly worse - the scales don't even compare - to Syrians. We're still incredibly 'lucky' they haven't decided to take out their big guns against us.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It won't even be the first country they're destroying which is why I'm sometimes baffled it took many people by surprise. My conviction remains that this is due to the fact that most people in Lebanon simply do not pay much attention to Syria, not in any great detail anyway.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: So their most hard-core followers have doubled and tripled down, just as they had to do to explain their presence in Syria away. What else will they do? They have nothing else to offer. No economic plan, no serious reform measures, nothing. Beirut blew up and they have nothing.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Well, Hezbollah has been losing its most precious asset since the October 2019 revolution: its narrative of resistance. Cracks were found early on, since 2015 or so, maybe before. Kinda awkward to call yourself pro-justice while being a primary vector of injustice in the region.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: In fact they were the ones with the power, them and the Iranian, Syrian and Russian governments. No rebel group at any point had anything close to what these four have combined. Even then it took them nearly a decade to slaughter their way to a Pyrrhic victory. So what now?

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It's not even just the human cost of their decision, which they're fine(ish) with ignoring or justifying away. It's simply the fact that it does not work. No enemy of theirs in Syria (and this was pre-ISIS) came close to Israel in terms of force.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: It tends to be forgotten that Nasrallah chose liberation (from Israel) day to announce his troops' presence in Syria in 2013. They made the decision to use their reputation as a resistance group to destroy Syrian resistance. That posed a problem for them.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: They knew that, so they had to use the exact same language used by the aforementioned governments - including Israel, ironically - and label all of their opponents as terrorists, takfiris, foreign agents etc.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Hezbollah's Syrian haunting will never go away, and they have no real plan for how to deal with it. They threw in their lot with the Assad regime - which is deeply unpopular in Lebanon, regardless of what they claim - and their actions have no reasonable justification.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: (it did get quite close to it during the 2008 conflict when they militarily took over parts of Beirut and Mount Lebanon, but they quickly tried to diffuse tension as they had the upper hand)

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: Hezbollah didn't need to use it as much prior to the 2011 revolutions. Nasrallah was even fine with supporting the revolutions elsewhere. But when it came to Syria, they shifted gear completely and wholly endorsed and made possible the most brutal counter-revolution in decades.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: I've made that argument in that Discontent piece on Hezbollah's 'Resistance™ against resistance'. The group utilised the same rhetoric against Syrians that is used against them by the Americans. Everyone's a terrorist or a foreign agent or a Takfiri. https://t.co/VQqRU7blnB

@MalakaShwaikh @a_delatolla Not on the spot, but it's just part of wider debates I've seen that do mention the different types of sanctions.

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: @a_delatolla @MalakaShwaikh In other words, yes warlords and oligarchs tend to take extra precautions but not always. They can be victims of their own arrogance and stupidity

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: @a_delatolla @MalakaShwaikh And don't forget that many of these people have comfortably assumed that their bank accounts in the EU (for example) are safe, that they may have not even taken the extra precautions to go for a specific Swiss bank or whatever because they never thought they'd have to deal w this

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet: @a_delatolla @MalakaShwaikh Certain sanctions can mean that their offshore accounts would be more difficult to access depending on the various regulations, which would put them under pressure. If they have a bank account in Europe, even Switzerland, there could be ways

name: 🌻 Joey Ayoub #EndKafala
tweet:
@MalakaShwaikh So the problems wouldn't be even the sanctions in this case but the global offshore accounts and corruption in the financial world. 

And to be clear, I don't think they'll happen anyway.
